moves.1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 exd4 4. Nxd4 N: This is bad. Just count how many pieces each side has developed before and after the exchange. Correct was 4...Nf6.
moves.5. Qxd4: The queen and pawn give White total dominance over the centre.
moves.5... h6: Unnecessary, but the obvious 5...Nf6 doesn't work either because of 6.e5. 5...d6 looks like the best option.
moves.6. Bc4 Qf6: It's fine if he takes it, but if he doesn't it obstructs the knight. It's usually unwise to bring out your queen so early in the game.
moves.7. e5 Qf5 8. Qd5 c6: 8...Ne7 developing a piece, looks better. Then after ...Ng6 (or ...Nc6) and ...Be7 you wll be able to castle. 8...c6 creates a hole on d6 which White exploits later.
moves.9. Qd2: A strange place to put the queen!
I don't see the point of this. You really should be thinking about getting your other bishop out and getting your king to safety.
moves.17... Bxd2+ 18. Rxd2: Although he is two pawns down, White has a winning position. All his pieces are active and he is on the verge of a breakthrough.
moves.18... O-O: I think there were better moves. 18...Qf4 or 18...Kd8.
moves.19. Rxh6 Ng6 20. Rd6: 20.Nf6  forces him to sacrifice his queen or he will be mated next move.
moves.20... Kg7 21. Qh5: I think Nf6 was still the best move.
moves.21... Rh8 22. Rf6: If you'd exchanged rooks first you would have won.
